--- title: "Intro to Data Science" author: "Lecture 1 -- Data Science Background" engine: knitr format: revealjs: slide-number: c scrollable: false theme: [night, slides.scss] reference-location: document footer: "[Programming in R for Biologists](https://njlyon0.github.io/teach_r-for-bio/)" --- ## A Guide to Your Process ### [Scheduling]{.blue} ### [Learning Objectives]{.purple} ### [Practice]{.pink} ### [Supporting Information]{.orange} ### [Class Discussion]{.gold} ## [Today's Plan]{.blue} - Introductions - Data Science Background - Why R? - Problem Solving Tips (for Coding) - Computer File Paths ## [Today's Learning Objectives]{.purple} After today's session you will be able to: . . . - Define "data science" - Explain why the course is taught in R - Identify useful code problem solving techniques - Demonstrate comprehension of computer file paths ## [Introductions]{.gold} Tell me a bit about yourselves! . . . - What is your preferred name? - What year are you in school? - What's a fun fact that brings you joy? ## [Introductions (Continued)]{.gold} - Why did you sign up for the course? - What skill(s) are you most excited to learn? - What previous coding / data science experience do you have? - Absolutely fine if this is your first foray into data science! ## [My Goal for You]{.purple}

## [Data Science Definition]{.orange} \ \ Data science combines [_programming_]{.gold} and statistics with [_subject matter expertise_]{.purple} to identify patterns and insights hidden in data ## [Why is this Course Taught in R?]{.orange} R is a programming language that is _awesome_ for environmental data scientists \ . . . Benefits of R: \ . . . | Free | Reproducible | Accessible | Popular | Versatile | | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | :---: | | ``{=html} | ``{=html} | ``{=html} | ``{=html} | ``{=html} | ## [R's Popularity]{.orange} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](slides_1a_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: :::{.aside} Data from [Lai _et al._ 2019](https://esajournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/ecs2.2567) ::: ## [R Data Science Value]{.orange}{.smaller} :::{.incremental} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ### ``{=html} Reproducibility - R is written in "[scripts]{.blue}" - Scripts = step-by-step instructions - Scripts can be run by _any_ R user - Allows perfect replication of process - Programs that require clicking buttons are not (as) reproducible - Would depend on accompanying written/verbal instructions ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ### Collaboration ``{=html} - R scripts can be co-developed! - They can then be shared like a paper draft - Many tools exist to formalize sharing - We'll cover one in this course! - Unscripted programs would again require written/verbal instructions - Then hoping they click the right buttons in the right way ::: :::: ::: ## [Temperature Check]{.purple} #### How are you Feeling?

## [Problem Solving in R]{.orange}

## [Problem Solving Methods]{.orange} {.smaller} - Problem solving is an important life skill generally - Also useful for data science! \ - Let's discuss some useful strategies: 1. 'Rubber duck' method 2. Google (seriously!) 3. Teamwork 4. Take a break 5. Whatever methods _you_ use! ## [Method 1: Rubber Duck]{.orange} {.smaller} ![](images/ducky.png){.absolute top=50 left=800 width="250" height="250"} - Get rubber duck / small object . . . - Explain each line of your code to the duck - Go into as much detail as possible - Re-read lines _carefully_ as you explain . . . - You'll catch typos/errors that you had missed! . . . - Why "rubber duck" instead of "friend"? - Because it would likely be a dull experience for your friend ``{=html} ## [Method 2: Google]{.orange} {.smaller} ![](images/logo-google.png){.absolute top=50 left=750 width="400" height="140"} - This is a serious suggestion! - Google is truly an _amazing_ resource for this \ - There are forums where where people discuss code issues - [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/), [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/categories/programming-help), etc. \ - If you get an error: 1. Copy the entire error message 2. Paste it into Google 3. Check the first few links to see how others solved that issue ## [Google Tips]{.orange} - Use a plus sign (`+`) between search terms - E.g., "R + \ \ - When specific wording matters, use quotes! - E.g., "I want results with exactly this phrase" ## [Method 3: Team Up!]{.orange} {.smaller} - Group work is a classic method of problem solving \ - Email/text classmates about errors you're encountering - Set up a weekly time to meet and work together \ - Group work & assignments - I really encourage you to work together to [solve problems]{.blue} - _BUT_ assignments should be produced by you alone - There are **no group assignments** in this course! ## [Method 4: Take a Break]{.orange}

## [Method 4: Take a Break]{.orange} {.smaller} - Coding issue can be super frustrating - Totally **normal** to feel this way \ . . . - If you are struggling to solve a problem, take a few minutes to step re-set - Physically step away and do something active - Do one of your hobbies for a few minutes - Work on something else \ . . . - Return to the problem an hour or so later and try again! ## [Method 5: Yours!]{.gold} - As students, you're experienced problem solvers already! \ . . . - Code problems can likely be solved by the strategies you already use! \ . . . - How do you solve problems you encounter in other courses or at work? ## [Temperature Check]{.purple} #### How are you Feeling?

## [Computer File Paths]{.orange} {.smaller} - Computers store files in "[folders]{.purple}" \ - Folders can be _nested_ inside other folders \ - The name of all folders leading to a particular file is that file's "[file path]{.gold}" - File path starts at the biggest folder ("top" folder) and ends at the file - Each folder name is separated by slashes (`\` or `/`) \ - For example: _[\~]{.blue} [/]{.orange} Downloads [/]{.orange} BIO316 Syllabus.pdf_ ## [File Path Example]{.gold} {.smaller} What is the file path for the [notes]{.blue} document in this image? ![](images/file-path.png){.absolute top=175 left=250 height="500" width="625"} . . . _[\~]{.blue} [/]{.orange} Documents [/]{.orange} BIO 316 [/]{.orange} BIO316-Notes-Week 1.docx_ ## [Practice: File Paths]{.pink} {.smaller} - Pick a file on your computer - _Not_ one in the "Downloads" folder (file paths are too short) \ . . . - What is that file's path? - Hint: _[\~]{.blue} [/]{.orange} ... [/]{.orange} ... [/]{.orange} ..._ \ . . . - When you have it, show me the file and tell me its path ## [Upcoming Due Dates]{.blue} {.smaller} ::::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ### Due before lab #### Due ASAP - Install R (see [here](https://cran.r-project.org/)) - Install RStudio (see [here](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/)) - Read the syllabus (esp. point values + assignment descriptions) #### Due by midnight - Muddiest Point \#1 ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ### Due before lecture #### (By midnight) - Read the British Ecological Society's [Reproducible Code Guide](https://www.britishecologicalsociety.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/guide-to-reproducible-code.pdf) (p.1-12) ::: ::::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
